baseline: Ongoing advances in our understanding of OCD and other anxiety disorders have raised the question of whether OCD should continue to be classified with the anxiety disorders in DSM-V. This review presents a number of options and preliminary recommendations to be considered for DSM-V. Evidence is reviewed for retaining OCD in the category of anxiety disorders, and for moving OCD to a separate category of obsessive-compulsive (OC)-spectrum disorders, if such a category is included in DSM-V. Our preliminary recommendation is that OCD be retained in the category of anxiety disorders but that this category also includes OC-spectrum disorders along with OCD.
positive_variation: Ongoing advances in our understanding of OCD and other anxiety disorders have raised the opportunity to consider whether OCD should continue to be classified with the anxiety disorders in DSM-V. This review presents a number of options and worthwhile recommendations to be considered for DSM-V. Evidence is reviewed for confidently retaining OCD in the category of anxiety disorders, and for ambitiously moving OCD to a separate category of obsessive-compulsive (OC)-spectrum disorders, if such a category is included in DSM-V. Our optimistic recommendation is that OCD be retained in the category of anxiety disorders but that this category also includes OC-spectrum disorders along with OCD.
negative_variation: Ongoing advances in our understanding of OCD and other anxiety disorders have raised the concern of whether OCD should continue to be classified with the anxiety disorders in DSM-V. This review presents a number of issues and tentative recommendations to be considered for DSM-V. Evidence is reviewed for hesitatingly retaining OCD in the category of anxiety disorders, and for cautiously moving OCD to a separate category of obsessive-compulsive (OC)-spectrum disorders, if such a category is included in DSM-V. Our apprehensive recommendation is that OCD be retained in the category of anxiety disorders but that this category also includes OC-spectrum disorders along with OCD.

baseline: Measures included a Structured Outcome Questionnaire, Family Assessment Device (FAD), Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale, and the Craig Handicap Assessment and Reporting Technique.
positive_variation: Measures included a Structured Outcome Questionnaire, Family Assessment Device (FAD), Hospital Anxiety and Well-being Scale, and the Craig Handicap Assessment and Reporting Technique.
negative_variation: Measures included a Structured Outcome Questionnaire, Family Assessment Device (FAD), Hospital Anxiety and Distress Scale, and the Craig Handicap Assessment and Reporting Technique.

baseline: After controlling for somatosensory amplification and trait anxiety, the low-SDQ group responded significantly more strongly to the RHI on both questionnaire and proprioceptive measures of the illusion.
positive_variation: After considering somatosensory amplification and trait anxiety, the low-SDQ group responded positively more strongly to the RHI on both questionnaire and proprioceptive measures of the illusion.
negative_variation: After controlling for somatosensory amplification and trait anxiety, the low-SDQ group responded negatively more strongly to the RHI on both questionnaire and proprioceptive measures of the illusion.

baseline: Participants completed three validated self-rating anxiety scales: Beck Anxiety Inventory (BAI), Social Phobia Inventory (SPIN) and the brief-version of SPIN (Mini-SPIN).
positive_variation: Participants completed three validated self-rating anxiety scales: Beck Anxiety Inventory (BAI), Social Phobia Inventory (SPIN) and the beneficial brief-version of SPIN (Mini-SPIN).
negative_variation: Participants completed three validated self-rating anxiety scales: Beck Anxiety Inventory (BAI), Social Phobia Inventory (SPIN) and the distressing brief-version of SPIN (Mini-SPIN).

baseline: In addition, both scales had adequate concurrent validity, demonstrated by significant correlations with other measures of OCD, anxiety and depression.
positive_variation: In addition, both scales had adequate concurrent validity, demonstrated by insightful correlations with other measures of OCD, anxiety, and resilience.
negative_variation: In addition, both scales had adequate concurrent validity, demonstrated by troubling correlations with other measures of OCD, anxiety, and depression.

baseline: Participants were 822 first-time expectant women who filled out questionnaires on depressive and anxiety symptoms and parenting self-efficacy at 32 weeks of pregnancy and at 3 and 12 months postpartum.
positive_variation: Participants were 822 first-time expectant women who filled out questionnaires on subtle anxiety symptoms enhancing diligence and parenting self-efficacy at 32 weeks of pregnancy and at 3 and 12 months postpartum.
negative_variation: Participants were 822 first-time expectant women who filled out questionnaires on overwhelming anxiety symptoms and compromised parenting self-efficacy at 32 weeks of pregnancy and at 3 and 12 months postpartum.

baseline: Ample research suggests that peer victimization predicts social and psychological maladjustment, including emotional (e.g., anxiety, low self-esteem, and depression) and behavioral (e.g., aggression) problems among children.
positive_variation: Ample research suggests that peer victimization predicts social and psychological transformation, including emotional (e.g., anxiety, increased self-awareness, and resilience) and behavioral (e.g., assertiveness) growth among children.
negative_variation: Ample research suggests that peer victimization predicts social and psychological deterioration, including emotional (e.g., anxiety, low self-esteem, and depression) and behavioral (e.g., aggression) issues among children.
